video.title_en: How Do We Know Nerves Aren't Magic?

summary.text_en: Hermann von Helmholtz conducted a foundational experiment that, for the first time, measured the *speed* of a nerve impulse. It was previously assumed that 'thought' or 'will' was transmitted *instantaneously* (at infinite speed). By isolating a frog's sciatic nerve and its attached muscle and using a 'myograph' to record the time-lag between stimulus and contraction, Helmholtz calculated the speed to be a surprisingly *slow*, measurable, physical velocity: about 27 meters per second (or 60 miles per hour).
key_points_en: Proved that thought and sensation are *not* instantaneous
Calculated nerve impulse speed at ~27 m/s

story.text_en: In 1850, the dominant 'Vitalism' theory held that a non-physical 'vital spark' animated the body, was not subject to physical laws, and traveled instantaneously. Helmholtz, a firm 'materialist', believed living bodies *must* obey the laws of physics, like his own 'Conservation of Energy' (`helmholtz_energy_conservation_1847`). To prove it, he designed an ingenious experiment: He dissected a frog's leg (gastrocnemius muscle) with its long sciatic nerve attached. He used a timer (myograph) to measure the lag between stimulating the nerve at point A (close to the muscle) and the muscle twitch. He then measured the lag from point B (farther up the nerve). He found that stimulating point B *always* resulted in a *tiny delay* compared to point A. By dividing the *distance* (B-A) by the *time delay*, he had clocked the physical speed of the 'vital spark'.

fun_facts.text_en: Helmholtz's finding of ~27 m/s was *scandalous* at the time. It proved that the speed of thought (about 60 mph) was significantly *slower* than the speed of sound (about 760 mph).
This experiment founded the entire field of 'Reaction Time' studies in psychology.

simple_explanation.text_en:
In 1850, people thought your 'soul' or 'will' moved *instantly*â€”when you decided to move your finger, the signal arrived at the same moment.
Helmholtz was the first to say, 'Really? Let's time it.'
He took a frog nerve (a wire) and its muscle (a lightbulb). He timed how long it took the signal to get from one end of the 'wire' to the other. He discovered the 'vital signal' was shockingly slow: only about 27 meters per second (60 mph).
He proved that 'thought' is not a magical spark, but a *slow, measurable, physical (electrical) process*.

applications.text_en: This work founded 'neurophysiology', the science of measuring and understanding the function of the nervous system using the tools of physics and chemistry.

applications.text_en: All modern neurological diagnostic tools, like Electromyography (EMG) and Nerve Conduction Velocity (NCV) tests, are the direct descendants of this first measurement.

applications.text_en: Helmholtz later applied this technique to humans to measure 'reaction time', effectively founding experimental psychology.

impact.text_en: This experiment was one of the most important in 19th-century biology. It dragged the 'nervous system' (and by extension, the 'mind' and 'soul') from the realm of sacred philosophy into the realm of measurable, materialist *physics*. It was the definitive proof that life processes obey the same laws of physics (like his Conservation of Energy) as the non-living world. This is the true birthdate of 'Neuroscience'.

influenced_by.contribution_en: Luigi Galvani (his 'animal electricity' was the phenomenon Helmholtz sought to 'quantify' and 'physicalize')
(Himself) The Conservation of Energy (this experiment was an extension of his belief that life must obey physical laws)

influenced.contribution_en: Wilhelm Wundt (his 'experimental psychology' lab was founded on Helmholtz's 'reaction time' work)
Hodgkin & Huxley (who finally explained *mathematically* *how* the electrical signal Helmholtz measured is generated)

influence_chain.legacy_text_en: Helmholtz was the first person to 'put a stopwatch on thought' and prove it was a slow, physical process.

quiz.question_en: What long-held philosophical belief did Helmholtz's 1850 frog nerve experiment overthrow?
options_en: That the 'vital force' and nerve signals were 'instantaneous'
That muscles were made of water
That frogs do not have souls
quiz.explanation_en: Before Helmholtz, it was assumed the 'will' or 'vital force' traveled infinitely fast (instantaneously). Helmholtz *measured* it and proved it was a relatively slow (approx. 27 m/s), entirely physical process.
